CatDescriptText: Mr. Robert Faix, salesman, Tarentum, and Mr. Fred Fiske, salesman, East Liberty, were part of the Pittsburghers Speak Up column, published in the Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, April 30, 1960, pg. 37 with question: "Do you think the religious issue will play a major role in the selection of the Democratic party's nominee for the Presidency of the United States?" Mr. Robert Faix's answer reads: "....Some effect, but not a major one...."  Mr. Fred Fiske's answer reads: "...It's a fact that Kennedy receives the majority of votes where Catholics predominate and the Protestant candidate received the majority from a Protestant area.  The Democratic party can't gamble on the religious whims of the voters, therefore, I think the ticket will be Symington and Johnson.  However, it's possible that Kennedy will win, because the people will vote, just vote, and forget about religion..."
TitMainTitle: Two frames: Portrait of Robert Faix wearing dark suit and sunglasses, standing in front of Bud Saunders Flowers, in Jenkins Arcade, Liberty Avenue, Downtown; Portrait of Fred Fiske wearing sunglasses and dark suit, standing in front of Bud Saunders Flowers, in Jenkins Arcade, Liberty Avenue, Downtown
